Borrower  People’s Republic of Bangladesh

Project Description  The  Project  has  four  outputs:  (i)  enhanced  relevance  of  and 
access to technical and vocational education and training (TVET) 
programs, (ii) improved capacity for good quality TVET delivery, 
(iii)  delivery  of  relevant  skills  training,  and  (iv)  project 
management. 
 
To enhance the relevance of TVET, the Project will support the 
(i) establishment of partnerships with industry; (ii) development of 
competency and training standards; (iii) development of curricula, 
teacher guides, learning materials and assessment tools; and (iv) 
capacity development in external competency assessment. 
 
With  a  view  to  improving  the  capacity  to  deliver  good  quality 
training programs, the Project will assist in (i) providing in-service 
training  to  government  and  nongovernment  TVET  teachers; 
(ii) revitalizing two public TVET teacher training institutions; (iii) 
strengthening the capacity for short training programs in selected 
public and private training institutions; and (iv) strengthening the 
capacity  of  the  Directorate  of  Technical  Education  (DTE)  for 
planning, research, and social marketing.  
 
To increase the delivery of relevant skills training, the Project will 
support (i) the delivery of skills training (market-responsive skills 
training) needed in the labor market, and (ii) the delivery of skills 
training in poor communities.  
   
Rationale  The TVET system has a large role to play in economic growth and 
social development as a provider of (i) trained human resources to 
the labor market and (ii) skills to those looking for employment. 
Bangladesh’s  national  poverty  reduction  strategy  (NPRS) 
recognizes the potential contribution of TVET to poverty reduction 
while supporting economic growth by providing employable skills, 
particularly to those who dropped out of school early and are 
already of employable age, and to the large pool of unemployed 
and underemployed adults.

ii   
  The current formal TVET system lacks linkage with and, therefore, 
relevance to the labor market. The capacity of the system to meet 
the needs of the labor market is small. Employers are looking for 
more  workers  who  can  meet  their  semiskilled  and  skilled 
requirements. The outputs of the TVET system and the needs of 
the employment sectors are mismatched in at least three areas: 
(i)  trades  or  occupations  where  programs  are  offered, 
(ii)  competencies  acquired  do  not  meet  industry  or  self-
employment  requirements,  and  (iii)  practical  experience 
opportunities  for  students.  The  practical  component  of  the 
curriculum is not effectively taught. The majority of TVET teachers 
lack  pedagogical  training  and  practical  skills,  and  have  no 
industrial experience. In addition, TVET institutions have poorly 
equipped workshops; and lack teaching and training materials, 
and adequate classrooms and workshops. 
 
The  formal  TVET  system  provides  limited  opportunities  to  the 
primary target beneficiaries of the NPRS. Successful completion 
of  class  (or  grade)  8  is  required  for  entry  into  formal  TVET 
programs in the secondary school certificate (vocational) and thus 
excludes the majority of the poor. Its main clientele are young 
adolescents who complete class 8, can afford to stay more years 
in school, and have strong white-collar job aspirations.  
 
The NPRS calls for a reform of the TVET system to make it more 
market-responsive; address training needs of the underprivileged 
who do not complete class 8; collaborate with the private sector 
and nongovernment organizations (NGOs); and make its training 
programs  more  flexible  in  terms  of  duration,  curriculum  and 
students’ academic qualifications, among others.  
   
Impact and Outcome  The Project’s impact will be increased wage- and self-employment 
of graduates of skills training. The Project supports the NPRS to 
reduce  poverty  and  promote  economic  growth  by  providing 
market-relevant skills training to more Bangladeshis, including the 
poor and disadvantaged 
 
The Project’s envisioned outcome is strengthened capacity of the 
TVET system to provide market-responsive, short-term, relevant 
skills training to more Bangladeshis, including those who have not 
completed class 8. The Project will be implemented throughout 
the country.  
   
Project Investment Plan   The investment cost of the Project is estimated at $66.7 million, 
including taxes and duties of $7.8 million.

iii
Financing Plan  A loan of $50,000,000 in various currencies equivalent to Special 
Drawing  Rights  (SDR)  30,741,000  will  be  provided  from  the 
Special Funds resources of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
to finance 75% of the project costs. The loan will have a 32-year 
term including a grace period of 8 years, with an interest charge of 
1%  per  annum  during  the  grace  period  and  1.5%  per  annum 
thereafter. 
   
Period of Utilization  1 June 2008–30 November 2013 
   
Estimated Project  31 May 2013 
Completion Date 
   
Executing Agency  Ministry of Education (MOE) 
   
Implementation  The  Directorate  of  Technical  Education  (DTE)  will  be  the 
Arrangements  Implementing  Agency  and  have  overall  responsibility  to  plan, 
organize, manage, and monitor the Project, as well as monitor 
progress.  The  project  implementation  unit  (PIU)  will  be 
responsible  for  day-to-day  project  implementation  and  overall 
coordination among all stakeholders. The PIU will be headed by a 
full-time project director who will be selected in consultation with 
ADB. An additional project director, seconded from senior DTE 
staff, will assume the functions for finance and administration and 
public–NGO partnership, in addition to duties as overall deputy to 
the project director.  
 
A project steering committee (PSC) will be formed and chaired by 
the  MOE  secretary.  The  PSC  will  be  responsible  for  detailed 
policy formulation, provide guidance and advice to the Project, 
and approve the Project’s annual work plan. It will approve the 
selection  criteria  for  (i)  TVET  institutions  eligible  for  program 
strengthening, (ii) market-responsive training proposals eligible for 
project support, (iii) training providers of the market-responsive 
training programs to be tendered, and (iv) criteria for selecting the 
40 educational institutions that will receive a training workshop. As 
the PSC is a large body that can only meet once a quarter, a 
project implementation committee, chaired by the director general, 
DTE,  will  be  established  to  oversee  day-to-day  project 
implementation. The project director will act as the committee’s 
member-secretary.  
   
Procurement  Procurement of goods and services will be in accordance with 
ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to 
time).  Disbursements  will  be  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Loan 
Disbursement Handbook (2007, as amended from time to time).

iv   
Consulting Services  The  selection  and  engagement  of  consultants  to  be  financed 
under the Project will be in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on 
the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). The 
consultant  services  will  include  about  97  person-months  of 
international  consulting  and  260  person-months  of  national 
consulting. International and national consulting services will be 
engaged through a firm, to be selected using the quality- and cost-
based  selection  method  and  a  full  technical  proposal,  in  the 
following specializations: TVET policy and competency standards 
development,  competency-based  training  curriculum,  materials, 
and  assessment  tools  development,  TVET  institution 
strengthening, TVET teacher training and planning, TVET training 
program design and packaging, training financing management 
design,  training  needs  assessment,  gender  and  indigenous 
people,  and  procurement  and    financial  management.  The 
external  independent  financial  assessment  and  external 
independent performance assessment specialists will be recruited 
individually. 
   
Project Benefits and  In general, the Project will initiate reform-oriented processes of 
Beneficiaries  TVET  system  operations  to  make  TVET  more  demand-driven, 
flexible, and oriented to serving the poor and disadvantaged. The 
pilot model on public–private sector collaboration will establish a 
linkage  between  TVET  authorities  and  training  providers,  and 
formal  and  informal  employment  markets,  thus  minimizing  the 
mismatch  between  supply  and  demand  for  labor.  The 
development  and  use  of  competency  standards  approved  or 
recognized by industry will introduce a new approach to the TVET 
system to give more value to actual competencies acquired than 
to traditional qualifications. Revitalization of the two public TVET 
teacher  training  institutions  will  support  an  expanded  teacher 
training system that serve the preservice and in-service teacher 
training  needs  of  the  government  TVET  sector,  and  those  of 
private and nongovernment training providers. In-service training 
of  TVET  teachers  addresses  the  immediate  need  of  TVET 
providers to provide untrained teachers with both pedagogical and 
technological skills; this will contribute to improving the quality of 
skills training delivery.   
 
The  Project  will  help  increase  access  to  skills  training  for  the 
larger segment of Bangladesh’s population. The development of 
short,  modular  competency-based  training  (CBT)  courses  will 
provide greater flexibility in terms of duration and required student 
academic  qualifications.  Offering  training  programs  not 
necessarily requiring class 8 for enrolment will expand access to 
the  TVET  system  to  those  that  did  not  attain  this  level  of 
education,  many  of  whom  are  poor.  Training  workshops  in 
selected poor communities will make training more accessible. 
Thus, the Project will open TVET institutions to a larger number of 
trainees in short CBT courses, most of whom would have been 
denied access because of the class 8 requirement for entry.

v
  Economic  benefits  of  the  Project  are  derived  mainly  from 
(i) increased access to skills training as a result of developing 
short,  modular  CBT  courses;  training  delivery  support;  and 
program  strengthening  of  selected  TVET  institutions;  and 
(ii)  improved  relevance  and  quality  of  skills  training  through 
partnerships  with  employers,  industry,  and  NGOs;  the  related 
revision of curricula; and provision of in-service teacher training. 
The Project will have about 68,200 trainees over the five years of 
implementation. The program strengthening of TVET institutions 
will expand the intake capacity of beneficiary training institutions. 
After the completion of their training, graduates are expected to 
seek local or international employment or be self-employed. With 
the  combined  efforts  to  increase  access  to  short-term  skills 
training programs and improve their relevance and quality, the 
proportion of trainees employed from Project-supported training 
programs is expected to improve. Although they are not the target 
beneficiaries of the Project, improving the quality of teaching and 
practical  training  in  vocational  subjects  is  also  expected  to 
improve the examination pass rates and employment likelihood of 
secondary school students in the vocational stream. Under these 
assumptions, the economic internal rate of return is estimated at 
13.9% in the base-case scenario.    
   
Risks and Assumptions  The partnership model assumes the continued commitment and 
cooperation of the three partner industry associations and NGOs 
in the sector working committees (SWCs). Thus, the Project will 
sign  memoranda  of  understanding  and  provide  strengthening 
activities to SWC members. The three focus industries and NGOs 
are eligible for training partnership assistance and their training 
requirements will be supported through the provision of market-
responsive  skills  training.  In  addition,  the  policy  development 
activities of the European Commission and International Labour 
Organization  (EC–ILO  project),  which  will  be  concurrently 
implemented, will reinforce linkages with industry and coordination 
of TVET-related government agencies. 
 
Implementation of the Project’s capacity development for external 
competency  assessment  that  will  recognize  prior  learning 
assumes that the EC–ILO project activity to develop the related 
policy and system will be at an advanced stage by the end of the 
Project’s second year of implementation. The Project will closely 
coordinate  with  the  EC–ILO  project  and,  if  any  delay  is 
experienced  in  that  project,  the  Project’s  specialists  in  TVET 
policy  and  competency  standards  development  and  CBT 
curriculum, materials and assessment tools development will help 
prepare the draft of the relevant policy and its supporting system.  
 
The Project aims to provide in-service training to about 4,000 
untrained TVET teachers from public and private TVET providers. 
However,  substitute  teachers  may  not  be  available  while  the 
untrained  teachers  are  on  training.  This  will  be  addressed  by

vi   
making the training program modular, short, and continuing; and 
scheduling teacher training when student training programs are 
not  in  session.  The  Project’s  loan  assurances  provide  for 
certification by the Bangladesh Technical Education Board of the 
in-service  teacher  training.  EC–ILO  activities  in  TVET  teacher 
qualifications  and  teacher  strengthening  will  complement  this 
activity.  
 
The limited scope of activities in the two public TVET teacher 
training institutions contributed to past underutilization. The new 
approach  to  include  a  multiparty  advisory  board;  in-service 
outreach  training;  and  training  of  staff  from  private  and  NGO 
sectors, and other ministries will help increase utilization of TVET 
facilities.  Management  training  for  administrators  will  facilitate 
addressing the training needs of non-MOE staff. Complementary 
inputs from the Project (facilities and staff development) and the 
EC–ILO project (policies and capacity strengthening) will support 
improvements in the quality and relevance of TVET, which should 
maintain  the  demand  for  the  preservice  and  in-service  TVET 
teacher training programs.     
 
The pace of implementation of market-responsive skills training 
will depend on the PIU’s capacity to identify priority and/or urgent 
training needs, package the corresponding training programs for 
tendering, and administer training contracts. To minimize the risk 
of delays, the Project will provide an adequate number of highly 
qualified staff, including for contracts administration, in the PIU 
and give support to the evaluation committees. The PIU will also 
be  supported  by  international  and  national  consultants 
specializing  in  training  financing  management  design,  training 
program design and packaging, and financial management.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the People’s Republic of Bangladesh for the Skills Development Project. (The design and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1). 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES1 
2.  Despite the calamities that hit the country almost every year, Bangladesh‘s economic 
growth  averaged  5.7%  per  annum  from  2000  to  2006.2  Nonetheless,  about  half  of  the 
population lives below the national poverty line. While agriculture engages the majority of the 
population, its share in gross domestic product (GDP) is declining. Sources of economic growth 
are shifting gradually to the higher productivity industry and services sectors. Economic growth 
has been fueled largely by export-oriented industries, mainly textiles and garments, which 
accounted for about 72% of total export earnings in 2004. Other industries experiencing robust 
growth include leather, leather goods, and construction. In the services sector, the industries 
posting significant growth rates include post and telecommunication, land transport, wholesale 
and retail trade, and hotels and restaurants. The national economy is buoyed by remittances 
from overseas Bangladeshi workers; in 2006 remittances made up the second largest source of 
foreign exchange.   
 
3.  Economic  growth  combined  with  the  Government’s  pro-poor  policies  and  programs 
resulted in significant improvement of some human development indicators, notably reduced 
infant and maternal mortality, increased net school enrollment ratio, and achievement of gender 
parity in primary education. Primary enrollment has more than tripled since 1970 from 5.3 million 
to about 16.2 million in 2005, and the proportion of female enrollees has increased from 32% to 
50%. In 2005, the gross enrollment rate for primary education was about 93.7%.   
 
4.  Over  half  of  Bangladesh’s  working  age  population  was  in  the  labor  force  in  2003. 
Women’s labor force participation has increased notably from 1996, particularly in rural areas. 
Of those employed locally, about 80% were in the informal sector and mainly self-employed or 
day  laborers;  only  14%  were  engaged  in  wage-employment.  Most  employment  is  still  in 
agriculture,  forestry,  and  related  works  (49%),  followed  by  wholesale  and  retail  trade  and 
manufacturing. Other relatively large employers include transport, storage, and communication 
service;  community,  personal  service,  and  household  sector;  construction;  and  education 
services. More Bangladeshis are seeking employment outside the country, but their share of 
employment opportunities is small. While about half of these workers are unskilled, the number 
of semiskilled and skilled workers among those deployed is growing.  
 
5.  Achieving  accelerated  poverty  reduction  and  related  Millennium  Development  Goal 
targets  would  require  Bangladesh’s  economy  to  grow  by  7%–8%  per  annum.3  Significant 
investment is required to achieve this. Attracting investments will require improving governance 
and streamlining bureaucratic rules and regulations, and upgrading the skills and competencies 
of human resources. The national poverty reduction strategy (NPRS) recognizes the potential 
contribution of technical and vocational education and training (TVET) in reducing poverty while 
supporting  economic  growth.  TVET  provides  practical  job  skills,  particularly  to  those  who 
dropped out of school early and are already of employable age, and to the large pool of

A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
6.  In 2006, the World Bank conducted a tracer study involving more than 2,300 graduates 
of basic trade, certificate and diploma courses of public and private TVET institutions. The 
highest proportions of employed were among the higher secondary certificate (vocational) (HSC 
[Voc]) graduates at 30%, followed by diploma graduates at 21%, and basic trades at 18%. 
These courses, however, account for only a small proportion of total formal TVET enrollment. 
The lowest proportions of employed were among the secondary school certificate (vocational) 
(SSC  [Voc])  graduates  (4%)  and  higher  secondary  certificate  (business  management) 
graduates (5%), which also had the highest proportion of graduates pursuing further education. 
 
7.  During the focus group discussions and interviews in the preparation of this Project, 
employers  in  ready-made  garments  and  textiles,  light  engineering,  and  construction  said 
workers with the required skills were not readily available in the market. The shortage is keenly 
felt  particularly  in  construction  and  light  engineering  industries, as  many  of  their  skilled 
workers have sought employment out of the country. Training for their replacements takes time 
and is costly. In the case of ready-made garments, the shortage is caused mainly by sustained 
high growth in product demand, requiring rapid expansion of production capacity. Because the 
work is labor-intensive, this entails hiring a large number of workers within a short time, which 
often results in poaching workers from other garment firms.  
B.   Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
8.  Need to Improve Relevance. A major weakness of the current TVET system is its lack 
of linkage, and therefore relevance, to the labor market, i.e., the formal industry subsectors, 
informal  self-employment  subsector,  and  international  employment.  Mismatches  between 
outputs of the TVET system and needs of employers include (i) types of trades or occupations 
where programs being offered, (ii) competencies acquired compared with industry requirements 
or  needs  for  self-employment  opportunities,  and  (iii)  practical  experience  opportunities  for 
students. The identification of courses is not based on regular and systematic assessment of 
labor  market  needs.  Even  if  the  curricular  offerings  match  market  needs,  the  competency 
acquired  may  not  match  industry  requirements.  Employers  have  minimal  input  in  setting 
competency  standards,  determining  the  curriculum,  developing  the  testing  and  certification 
system, and managing certain training institutions, among others. There is wide scope for 
engaging industries in the TVET system, which has been barely tapped. During the consultation 
workshop and interviews to prepare the Project, industry leaders expressed willingness to 
cooperate with TVET system authorities. The international labor market is large but highly 
competitive.  About  half  of  the  current  deployment  of  Bangladeshi  workers  is  made  up  of 
unskilled laborers. An effective TVET system can increase the proportion of semiskilled and 
skilled  workers  by  using  industry-recognized  and  internationally  benchmarked  competency 
standards and training systems. TVET can be made more relevant to the informal sector, too, 
by such activities as upgrading skills in certain occupations. A number of NGOs have training 
programs catering to the informal rural subsector that are achieving high placement rates.  
9.  Need  to  Improve  Access.  The  existing  formal  TVET  system  provides  limited 
opportunities to target beneficiaries of the NPRS—the underprivileged who do not complete

3
class 8. Its main clientele are young adolescent males who complete class 8, can afford to stay 
more  years  in  school,  and  have  strong  white-collar  job  aspirations.  The  minimum  entry 
requirement to the lowest formal qualifications, basic skill standard certificate (national skills 
standard-basic) and national skill certificate III (national skills standard III), which is class 8, 
automatically excludes the large majority who do not achieve it. Promoting female enrolment in 
nontraditional trades is also needed. Until very recently, the lack of formal recognition by the 
Bangladesh Technical Education Board (BTEB) of successful NGO- and industry-delivered 
short  programs  inhibited  their  expansion.  Good  quality  competency-based  training  (CBT) 
modular courses offer the best vehicle for the TVET system to reach out to the poor. Short 
courses would be more affordable for trainees than the 2-year SSC (Voc) programs. Opening 
up TVET to the older poor by offering short CBT courses that do not necessarily require class 8 
for enrolment will increase TVET output, improve utilization of facilities, reduce unit costs, and 
make the system more relevant.  
10.  Need to Improve Quality and Capacity. The pass rate of students in the terminal 
external examination, conducted by BTEB, to a large extent reflects the quality of education and 
training. One of the major constraints to effective TVET delivery is the lack of trained teachers. 
The majority of TVET teachers have little pedagogical training, including in CBT delivery; lack 
practical skills; and have little or no industry experience. TVET teachers are interested in 
obtaining in-service training, and BTEB is considering pedagogical and technological training of 
TVET teachers as a requirement for the registration of private TVET institutions. The country 
needs  a  TVET  teacher  training  system  that  will  provide  preservice  training  and,  more 
importantly, will quickly and effectively provide teacher upgrading and introduce new curricula 
and teaching methodologies. The current TVET teacher training capacity in the country is 
limited. The two public TVET teachers’ training institutions, i.e., Technical Teachers Training 
College (TTTC) in Dhaka for diploma and degree programs and Vocational Teachers Training 
Institute (VTTI) in Bogra for diploma and certificate programs, presently serve only the needs of 
Ministry of Education (MOE) TVET institutions. Their facilities need upgrading and they need to 
support non-MOE TVET institutions, including government, nongovernment, and private.  
11.  The lack of trained teachers is compounded by the fact that the majority of private and 
some government TVET institutions have poorly equipped workshops and laboratories, lack 
teaching and training materials, and have inadequate classrooms and libraries. Consequently, 
the practical component of the curriculum is not effectively taught. The formal TVET system has 
minimal  capacity  to  meet  the  needs  of  the  labor  market.  Some  TVET  institutions  require 
substantial capital investments to increase their capacity to deliver short CBT programs.

encourage flexible reallocation of training resources to high-priority economic activities and

III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
15.  The Project’s impact will be increased wage- and self-employment of graduates of skills 
training, locally and internationally. The Project supports the Government’s NPRS to reduce 
poverty  and  promote  economic  growth  by  providing  market-relevant  skills  training  to  more 
Bangladeshis,  including  the  poor  and  disadvantaged.  The  Project’s  envisioned  outcome  is 
strengthened capacity of the TVET system to provide market-responsive, short-term, relevant 
skills training to more Bangladeshis, including those who have not completed class 8. The 
Project will be implemented throughout the country.

B.  Outputs 
16.  The  Project  adopts  a  market-responsive  approach  and  will  have  four  outputs:  (i) 
enhanced relevance and access of TVET programs; (ii) improved capacity for good quality 
TVET delivery; (iii) relevant skills training, including to the poor, women, and disadvantaged

1.   Enhanced Relevance and Access of TVET Programs  
17.  This  component  aims  to  enhance  the  relevance  of  training  programs  by  improving 
linkages to the labor market, and to increase access by developing short CBT programs. The 
Project will pilot the development of a partnership mechanism with three industries: ready-made 
garments and textiles, light engineering, and construction. Their selection is based on their 
relative importance to the economy in terms of employment generation, contribution to the 
national  output,  future  growth  prospects,  availability  of  a  formal  industry  association,  and 
interest  in  workforce  training.  The  Government  will  work  with  representatives  of  the  three 
industries and the informal sector (Appendix 5) to determine their specific skills training needs. 
The  outputs  are  (i)  partnerships  with  industry  established;  (ii)  competency  and  training 
standards developed; (iii) curricula, teacher guides, learning materials and assessment tools 
developed; and (iv) capacity in external competency assessment developed. 
18.  Partnerships with Industry Established. The Project will support establishment and 
operation of a sector working committee (SWC) in each of the three major industries and the 
informal sector. Each industry SWC will comprise 8–12 technically knowledgeable experts from 
the industry’s largest member associations. The informal sector SWC will comprise experts from 
the  largest and  most  successful  NGOs  delivering  skills  training  in  Bangladesh. To  ensure 
coordination and provide support to the SWCs, a forum of skill development partners will be 
established comprising heads of the four SWCs, heads of the largest industry associations in 
the three focus industries, and the head of the lead NGO in the informal sector SWC. The forum 
will interact with the BTEB chairperson and members, and other TVET stakeholders. SWC 
members  will  benefit  from  regional  and  national  capacity  building  activities  in  needs 
assessments, competency standards development, and public-private partnerships, including 
on international experiences for relevant government officials and industry representatives.  
19.  Competency and Training Standards Developed. Each SWC will identify 10 priority 
occupations (40 in total)6 for the development and dissemination of competency and training 
standards. Depending on the demand within the 40 priority occupations, the Project will support 
the development of about 100 competency standards by SWCs, most likely for basic trade and 
national  skills  standard  III.  The  standards7  will  be  approved  by  their  respective  industry 
stakeholders and endorsed to BTEB for its approval. For the approved competency standards, 
the SWCs, in coordination with BTEB’s curriculum development committees, will specify the 
training standards necessary to attain the competencies. The training standards will include 
specifications for training duration, number and qualifications of instructors, teaching materials, 
and assessment method.

capacity building activities will be undertaken to learn from other countries' external competency

37.  Public–Private Sector Partnership. Until now, TVET training providers and employers 
have conducted training activities independently, except for a few partnerships initiated by some 
NGOs and industry groups. The Project will pilot a partnership structure and processes to bring 
public authorities, training providers, employers, and NGOs together. The approach is market-
responsive rather than supply-driven. Employer representatives will identify occupations where 
training gaps exist and specify the required skills standards. The Project will provide resources 
for skills training development and addressing training gaps. Resources will be available for 
establishing or strengthening training partnerships between industry associations and public 
TVET institutions.

short,  modular  training  programs  based  on  competency  standards  set  by  industry.  The 
Government will certify the training programs to increase their recognition by employers. The 
short courses will diversify the system’s clientele, opening up opportunities for those unable to 
complete class 8, including the poor, women, and disadvantaged groups.

IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
A.  Benefits and Impacts 
60.  Institutional and Sectoral. The Project will initiate reform-oriented activities in TVET 
system operation with the goal of making it more demand-driven, flexible, and oriented toward 
increasingly serving the poor and disadvantaged. The pilot model on public–private sector 
collaboration will establish a linkage between the TVET authorities and training providers and 
the formal and informal labor markets to minimize the mismatch between supply and demand 
for labor. The development and use of industry-approved or -recognized competency standards 
will introduce a new approach to the TVET system that gives more value to actual competencies 
acquired than to traditional qualifications. The revitalization of the two key TVET teacher training 
institutions will support an expanded teacher training system that will also serve private and 
nongovernment  training  providers.  In-service  training  of  TVET  teachers  addresses  the 
immediate need of TVET providers to provide untrained teachers with both pedagogical and 
technological skills, which will contribute to improving the quality of skills training delivery.   
61.  Social. The development of short modular CBT courses will provide greater flexibility in 
terms of duration and required students’ academic qualifications. Offering training programs not 
necessarily requiring class 8 for enrolment will expand access to the TVET system to those who 
did not complete this required grade, many of whom are poor. Upgrading the facilities of TVET 
institutions will improve the capacity for delivering short, relevant training programs. Training 
workshops in selected poor communities will make training more accessible to the poor. Thus, 
the Project will open TVET institutions to a larger number of trainees in short CBT courses, most 
of whom would have been denied access because of the class 8 barrier to entry. As the training 
programs  will  be  demand-driven  and  based  on  industry-set  or  -recognized  standards, 
opportunities for employment and self-employment of trainees will improve.    
62.  Economic.  Economic  benefits  of  the  Project  are  derived  mainly  from  (i)  increased 
access to skills training as a result of developing short, modular CBT courses; training delivery 
support; and program strengthening of selected TVET institutions; and (ii) improved relevance 
and quality of skills training through the partnership with employers, industry, and NGOs; and 
the related revision of curricula and provision of in-service teacher training. The Project will have 
about 68,200 trainees over the five years of implementation. After completion of their training, 
the graduates are expected to seek local or international employment or be self-employed. 
Those who will be employed locally will contribute to increased domestic production because of

17
their  skills  training  (increased  human  capital)  that  will  be  reflected  in  increased  earnings. 
Graduates  who  will  be  employed  internationally  will  bring  increased  foreign  currency 
remittances into the country. With the combined efforts to increase access to short-term skills 
training and improve their relevance and quality, the proportion of trainees employed from the 
Project-supported training programs is expected to improve to 75% in 2015. Teacher training, 
improvements in the training curricula, and improved training facilities are also expected to 
benefit students enrolled in the SSC (Voc) and HSC (Voc) programs. Although they are not the 
target beneficiaries of the Project, improving the quality of teaching and practical training in 
vocational subjects is expected to improve examination pass rates and employment rates. 
Under these projections, the economic internal rate of return is estimated at 13.9% in the base-
case scenario (Appendix 16). 
B.  Risks and Assumptions 
63.  The partnership model assumes the continued commitment and cooperation of the three 
partner-industry associations and NGOs in the SWC. Thus, the Project will sign memoranda of 
understanding and provide strengthening activities to SWC members. The three focus industries 
and NGOs are also eligible for training partnership assistance. Their training requirements will 
be  supported  through  the  provision  of  market-responsive  skills  training.  In  addition,  the 
concurrent policy development activities of EC–ILO will reinforce linkages with industry and 
coordination  of  TVET-related  government  agencies.  The  Project’s  proposed  capacity 
development in external competency assessment for the recognition of prior learning assumes 
that the EC–ILO project activity to develop the related policy and system will be at an advanced 
stage by the end of the Project’s second year of implementation. The Project will closely 
coordinate with the EC–ILO project and, if any delay is experienced in that project, the services 
of the Project’s specialists in TVET policy and competency standards and CBT curriculum, 
materials and assessment tools development can help prepare the draft of the relevant policy 
and its supporting system to facilitate the process.  
64.  The Project aims to provide in-service training to about 4,000 untrained teachers from 
public and private TVET institutions. However, substitute teachers may not be available while 
the untrained teachers are on training. This will be addressed by making the training program 
modular, short, and continuous; and scheduling teacher training when student training programs 
are not in session. The Project’s loan assurances also provide for BTEB certification of the in-
service  teacher  training.  EC–ILO  activities  in  TVET  teacher  qualifications  and  teacher 
strengthening will complement this activity.  
65.  The  limited  scope  of  activities  in  the  two  key  TVET  teacher  training  institutions 
contributed to its underutilization. The new approach to include a multiparty advisory board, in-
service outreach training, and training for staff from the private and NGO sectors and other 
ministries will help increase utilization of TVET facilities. Management training for administrators 
will facilitate addressing the training needs of non-MOE staff. Complementary inputs from the 
EC–ILO project will support improvements in quality and relevance that should maintain the 
demand for the preservice and in-service TVET teacher training programs.

TECHNICAL AND VOCATIONAL EDUCATION TRAINING SUBSECTOR ANALYSIS 
1.  The contribution of the technical and vocational education and training (TVET) system to 
the supply of labor relative to total demand is minimal. However, the Government and the 
development community recognize the potential of TVET in providing employable skills to those 
who did not and would not pass through the school system; leave the school system early; and 
need higher skills even after completing the certificate, diploma, or degree courses. However, to 
achieve the goals of the national poverty reduction strategy, many aspects of TVET need to be 
addressed: relevance, quality, and access, in particular. 
A.   The Technical and Vocational Education Training System 
2.  The TVET system in Bangladesh may be classified into four groups: (i) public, (ii) private 
(commercial), (iii) nongovernment organization (NGO), and, (iv) industry (managed by industry 
associations and industry-provided on-the-job training). Each of these groups offers a wide 
variety of formal and nonformal training programs for various types of clientele using different 
types of training delivery. As of school year 2004-05, formal TVET was mostly offered by about 
2,728 institutions: 180 or 7% public and 2,548 or 93% private. Of the 17,185 teachers delivering 
TVET courses, 2,939 or 17% were in public institutions and 14,246 were in private institutions. 
Of the 241,336 total enrolment, 20% was in public and 80% in private institutions. Between 
school years 2001/02 and 2004/05, enrolment rose by about 80%.  
3.  Different  ministries  manage  the  public  institutions.  The  Directorate  for  Technical 
Education of the Ministry of Education (MOE) manages polytechnic and monotechnic institutes 
and technical schools and colleges; the Ministry of Labor manages technical training centers; 
the  Ministry  of  Textile  manages  textile  vocational  centers;  and  the  Ministry  of  Agriculture 
manages agricultural training institutes. The private institutions are mostly general secondary 
schools offering TVET courses alongside the general secondary curriculum. While the private 
TVET institutions are numerous, they are mostly small with an average of about 6 teachers and 
75 students per institution, compared with about 16 teachers and 272 students of the public 
sector, although their student–teacher ratios are not too different. In addition, other ministries 
and agencies provide nonformal TVET courses.1
4.  Formal TVET in Bangladesh consists of three program offerings—basic, certificate, and 
diploma—with class (or grade) 8 completion a minimum entry qualification. Basic trade (basic 
skill standard certificate or national skills standard-basic) is a 360-hour skills training course 
focusing mainly on practical skills with some theory requiring class 8 education. This is offered 
mainly at technical training centers and technical schools and colleges. The secondary school 
certificate (vocational) (SSC [Voc]) is a 2-year certificate course after class 8, and is attractive to 
students because of its equivalency to (i) the SSC of the general education stream, which 
provides entry to higher education; and (ii)  national skills standard II, which should provide 
entry into the world of work. National skills standard III is awarded after class 9 completion. SSC

5.  NGOs as TVET Providers. NGOs provide a variety of nonformal skills training directed 
to specific target groups such as the poor, women, and the marginalized; however, BTEB 
currently does not accredit this training. The majority of NGOs are small and lack physical 
facilities.  Being  immersed  in  the  communities  that  they  serve,  they  have  the  capability  to 
mobilize large numbers of people anytime, and with some help can effectively deliver quality 
training. Some NGOs have been highly effective in delivering skills training and have networks 
that extend to hard-to-reach areas. They provide an integrated approach to human development 
that  includes  not  only  skills  supported  with  microcredit,  but  also  teach  appropriate  work 
attitudes. NGOs often mentioned in this context are the Under-Privileged Children’s Education 
Program, Mirpur Agricultural Workshop and Training School, Caritas Mobile Skills Training, St. 
Joseph’s School, and Bangladesh Rural Advancement Committee (BRAC).  
6.  TVET  in  Industry.  A  study2  undertaken  during  project  preparation  found  that  the 
majority of workers mainly acquire their skills on-the-job. Those who acquired them formally 
mainly attended technical institutes. The majority (72%) of the firms surveyed indicated that they 
had no training facilities, and a small subgroup (12%) sent their workers to external training 
organizations for upgrading.   
7.  Some employer associations have training establishments. The Bangladesh Garments 
Manufacturers Export Association established the Institute of Fashion and Technology as a fully 
self-financed  training  institute.  Employers  established  the  Chittagong  Skills  Development 
Center, which is a model of industry–government cooperation. Development agencies and 
industry have partnered with MOE to upgrade industry-specific institutes for textiles, glass and 
ceramics, and leather. In addition, industry-specific training is available for railway, air, and 
marine operations. The Dhaka Chamber of Commerce and Industry received development 
agency assistance to establish logistics training.  
8.  Some labor brokers have their own training programs mainly to supply workers for major 
construction projects, e.g., pipelines and bridges, and for international employment. Some of the 
numbers are significant and aim to fulfill international standards, e.g., a contract to train and 
supply 20,000 construction workers in 2007 for employment in Singapore.

B.   TVET Issues  
9.  Training Quality. The quality of education and training is generally reflected in students’ 
pass rates in BTEB’s terminal external examination. During 2000–2004, the average pass rate 
for SSC (Voc) was about 45% for both male and female students or, conversely, 55% of those 
who finish SSC (Voc) fail to pass the final examination. No data is available on the pass rate of 
HSC (Voc).  
10.  The low pass rate for SSC (Voc) can be attributed to a number of factors affecting 
instruction quality. One is the short supply of qualified TVET teachers. The sudden expansion of 
TVET programs, particularly private and nongovernment, has not been matched by an equal 
supply of teachers. The majority of the teachers hired have no training on pedagogy and lack 
industry experience; no continuing staff development is available to address this deficiency. 
BTEB  estimates  that  about  24,000  TVET  teachers  in  the  private  sector  need  training.  In 
addition, all teachers need to be trained in the new competency-based curricula. Monitoring of 
actual teacher performance in the classrooms or workshops is lacking.  
11.  The capacity of TVET teacher training institutions is limited. The Vocational Teachers 
Training Institute (VTTI) has capacity for training 240 teachers only, and focuses training on 
developing new teachers for eight trades. The Technical Teachers Training College (TTTC) has 
capacity for 80 teachers, but has been producing fewer graduates. In addition, VTTI and TTTC 
serve only the MOE TVET teachers, leaving other training providers (i.e., government, private, 
or NGO) to seek other TVET teacher training programs. The VTTI and TTTC programs need to 
be  refocused  to  provide  good  quality  training,  including  in-service  training,  to  more  TVET 
teachers from both MOE- and non-MOE-administered institutions. The facilities of VTTI and 
TTTC need to be upgraded and capacity increased to provide outreach to private/NGO sector 
teachers. 
12.  Lack  of  equipment  compounds  the  situation  in  most  training  institutions,  in  some 
instances  outdated  equipment  or  equipment  is  no  longer  operating.  In  some  schools  new 
equipment is not used as instructors have not been trained in its operation. Consequently, the 
practical component of the curriculum is not effectively taught. And since most of the institutions 
do not have a linkage with industry, the industry attachment component of the curriculum is not 
effectively implemented.  
13.  Relevance of Training Programs. Ultimately, the main measure of success of the 
TVET system if it is to significantly contribute to poverty reduction is whether its graduates find 
gainful employment, preferably in the trade areas they are trained for. A World Bank tracer 
study in 2006 involving 2,302 graduates of public and private TVET institutions in 2003 found 
the proportion of employed to be low (see Table A2.1). The proportion of employed was highest 
among the higher secondary certificate (vocational) (HSC [Voc]) graduates at 30%, followed by 
diploma graduates at 21%, and basic trades at 18%. These courses, however, account for only 
a small proportion of total enrollment. While the lowest proportions of employed were among the 
SSC (Voc) graduates (4%) and HSC (business management) graduates (5%), the proportions 
of their graduates pursuing higher education were the highest. This finding indicates that these 
courses appear to be catering to a clientele who can afford to pursue higher education and have 
strong white-collar job aspirations; this is not consistent with the objectives of the national 
poverty reduction strategy. Across all the respondents, only 9% were employed, 45% were 
pursuing higher education and the rest were unemployed. Of those who were employed, about 
38% took less than 6 months to get a job and another 16% took up to a year. The employment 
outcomes of graduates of the public and private institutions indicated little difference.

15.  The formal TVET system has minimal impact on the economy and poverty reduction; of 
the total labor force in 2003, only 0.12% received technical training from the system. One of the 
features of the existing system is its focus on long courses such as the SSC (Voc) and HSC 
(Voc); the majority of successful graduates pursue further studies. While this helps keep young 
adolescents in school, it is an expensive route for accessing further education. Also contributing 
to the low output is the lack of formal BTEB recognition of successful NGO and industry 
delivered programs such as those offered by Mirpur Agricultural Workshop and Training School, 
Caritas, Under-Privileged Children’s Education Program, other NGOs, and the construction 
industry.  
16.  TVET can be made more relevant to the informal sector. The productivity of the sector 
can be improved by upgrading skills in certain occupations, e.g., motorbike repair, repair of farm 
implements, food processing, and carving. Mirpur Agricultural Workshop and Training School, 
Bangladesh Rural Advancement Committee, and other successful NGOs have a number of 
training programs catering to the informal rural subsector that have high employment rates. 
Usually  these  are  linked  with  microcredit.  Such  programs,  which  incorporate  modules  on 
entrepreneurship, can be mainstreamed by converting to competency-based training (CBT) 
(some already are) and recognized by BTEB so that they can be scaled up with Government 
and  development  agency  support.  The  competency-based  approach  to  skills  training 
emphasizes the acquisition of skills used in the workplace. Skills are according to the standards 
related to industry’s needs. Often, CBT is delivered in modules. Students progress to the next 
module after demonstrating acquisition of the skill rather than after a fixed time frame, and 
students can potentially complete training programs faster. 
17.  One of the main features of the formal TVET system is limited opportunities. All its 
programs, including the 6-month basic trades and SSC (Voc), require class 8 as minimum entry

18.  Governance and Management Structure. The scope of the TVET subsector is much 
wider  and  more  diverse  than  generally  understood.  It  encompasses  a  large  number  of 
institutions and activities. However, its impact has hardly been felt, partly because its various 
components lack a unifying vision in which  each has a clearly defined role. The need to 
rationalize the disparate efforts in TVET by putting it under a single regulatory framework to 
provide a unified and coherent direction was acknowledged as early as 1979 with the creation of 
the National Council for Skills Development and Training (NCSDT). NCSDT was to provide 
macro-level policy direction and other national services related to skills training, coordinate the 
efforts of different agencies involved in skills training to avoid duplication of efforts, and develop 
national competency standards. Despite the reconstitution of its membership in 1991, NCSDT 
has not functioned as intended. Several factors have been cited for its lack of effectiveness, 
including (i) membership is too big and difficult to coordinate and organize, although this was 
partly addressed in the revised composition; (ii) many members do not have the expertise nor 
interest in formulating policies related to the development of the workforce for crafts; (iii) the 
NCSDT secretariat (Bureau of Manpower, Employment and Training [BMET]) does not have 
sufficient resources and expertise to provide the necessary support to NCSDT; and (iv) BMET 
lacks autonomy, which is needed for effective functioning as the NCSDT secretariat. 
 19.  While the initial attempt to provide a unified governance and management structure did 
not work as expected, the need for it remains even more valid and urgent today. The options 
are either to reactivate NCSDT and build on the existing legal framework, or create a completely 
new but equivalent body. Presently, MOE has overall responsibility for making policy decisions 
for all education, including technical and vocational education. The execution of policies is 
vested in two of its agencies: Directorate for Technical Education and BTEB. Under the existing 
institutional arrangements, a major component is conspicuously missing—the involvement of 
private sector representatives, including employers, private training providers, and NGOs. They 
need to be involved not only for strategy and policy but for operations as well.   
20.  The management of training institutions needs to be addressed. Although BMET seems 
to  be  progressing  in  decentralization,  the  overly  centralized  system  of  the  Directorate  for 
Technical Education does not allow its principals to manage. They do not have authority to 
decide  on key  areas necessary  for  effective  functioning  of  their  institutions,  e.g.,  hiring  of 
teachers, discontinuing low-demand programs, and offering market-demanded programs. With 
clear guidelines and transparent procedures, heads of institutions should be able to select their 
teachers  for  approved  posts  and  have  the  authority  to  reward  or  penalize  depending  on 
performance. They should also be allowed to hire on a part-time basis. The authority to close 
down courses in trade areas with low market demand so that the resources can be channeled to 
the more promising areas should also be provided. With respect to short courses, principals 
should even have greater authority to be able to respond quickly to market needs. However, 
while  autonomy  is  certainly  needed  if  management  is  to  be  accountable  for  performance, 
management’s  readiness  to  assume  greater  responsibility  must  be  considered.  Thus,  a 
continuing management development program to build management capacity is needed.

1.  With a view to supporting the national poverty reduction strategy goal of expanding skill 
development to more Bangladeshis, the Project will strengthen the institutional capacity of 
public and private technical and vocational education and training (TVET) providers to deliver 
training programs comprising short competency-based training (CBT) courses developed under 
the Project. The Project1 will assist about 60 public training institutions, 15 private training 
institutions,  and  10  nongovernment  organization-managed  training  centers.  About  six 
partnerships between the industry associations in the sector working committees (SWCs) and 
existing  public  TVET  institutions  will  be  supported;  this  can  include  strengthening  industry 
training programs in partnership with TVET institutions and establishing new partnerships as 
necessary, including management of government TVET institutions by industry associations on 
pilot basis. Shortlisted TVET institutions will prepare program improvement plans (PIPs). TVET 
institutions will be selected based on a set of criteria to be approved by the project steering 
committee and the Asian Development Bank (ADB).  
 
2.  Eligible Items for Support. The Project will support expenditures necessary to upgrade 
the delivery of CBT courses in the selected technology areas to the desired quality as indicated 
in  the  approved  skills  and  training  standards.  These  include  (i)  rehabilitation  of  existing 
classrooms, laboratories, or workshops used for the selected programs; (ii) construction of 
additional classrooms, laboratories, or workshops attached to existing buildings, if all existing 
facilities are demonstrated to be fully utilized and accommodating the new CBT courses would 
be  difficult;  (iii)  purchase  of  equipment  and  furniture  for  classrooms,  laboratories,  and 
workshops for the selected programs; (iv) purchase of books, reference materials, teaching 
aids, and other supplementary materials; (v) rehabilitation or construction of basic water and 
sanitation facilities including separate toilets for women; and (vi) consumables for conducting 
the new CBT courses. 
 
3.  Draft Criteria for Selecting the Short List of TVET Institutions for Assistance. ADB 
and the project steering committee will approve the criteria. The main consideration in the 
selection process will be potential capacity, with project assistance, to deliver high-quality short 
CBT courses developed by the Bangladesh Technical Education Board based on competency 
standards set by the sector working committees (SWCs). The proposed selection criteria are  
(i) located where industries are available to provide employment at least within the locality and 
available  to  be  potential  partners for  specific  programs;  (ii)  management  capacity  to  plan, 
implement and manage a 3-year program improvement program; (iii) average size of enrollment 
over the past 3 years (both in long and short courses) to indicate demand for course offerings; 
(iv) pass rate of graduates in government terminal examinations, where applicable, over the 
past  3  years  to  indicate  the  effectiveness  and  quality  of  training  provision;  
(v) employment rate of graduates over the past 3 years to indicate relevance and quality of 
training programs; (vi) number and qualification of full-time teachers to indicate capacity to 
deliver new short CBT courses alongside existing programs at desired quality; (vii) capacity of 
existing training facilities in terms of classrooms, laboratories, and workshops and equipment; 
and additional investment needed to offer new short CBT courses alongside existing training 
programs; and (viii) extent of existing linkage with industry in terms of industrial internship, job 
placements and participation in institutional management at least in an advisory capacity.

A.  Economic Analysis 
 
1.  Labor Demand. The industry sector leads recent growth performance in Bangladesh, 
followed by the services sector. As a result, the economy is experiencing a gradual structural 
transformation  that  requires  a  more  technically  skilled  labor  force.  At  the  same  time, 
international demand for Bangladeshi labor is growing. During 1995–2005, about 2.58 million 
Bangladeshi workers were working outside of the country, of which 48% were unskilled, 15% 
semiskilled, 33% skilled, and only 4% professional. To withstand increasing competition from 
other labor-exporting countries, continuous skills upgrading is required. 
 
2.  Labor  Supply.  However,  with  the  growing  demand  for  skilled  labor,  a  sizeable 
proportion  of  the  labor  force  has  insufficient  or  inappropriate  schooling.  Of  those  that  are 
schooled, only 58,000 workers (55,000 male and 5,000 female) in the labor force received 
technical or vocational education; this represents 0.12% of the 46.3 million in the labor force. 
 
3.  Shortcomings of the Technical and Vocational Education (TVET) System. A major 
weakness of the current TVET system is the considerable mismatch between the system’s 
outputs  and  labor  market  needs.  The  poor  condition  of  the  TVET  system  is  the  result  of  
(i) teaching equipment lacking or malfunctioning, (ii) industrial attachment component of the 
curriculum rarely implemented, and the curriculum not relevant to or in demand by the industry, 
(iii) shortage of qualified teachers with practical skills, and (iv) focus on long courses. The 
system could greatly enhance its output by utilizing its slack capacity for the more employment-
oriented short courses and older students. The overall impact of the current TVET system on 
the economy is modest. A tracer study conducted by the World Bank involving 2,302 graduates 
of both public and private TVET institutions concluded that about 9% of TVET graduates were 
employed (7.3% wage-employed and 1.3% self-employed), 45% were pursuing further studies, 
and 47% were unemployed. 
 
4.  Solutions and Project Contribution. The Project responds to the analyzed needs and 
weaknesses of the TVET system and aims to increase its efficiency and effectiveness. It will 
enhance the relevance of the training programs for the domestic and international labor markets 
by piloting a partnership mechanism between the key players on the supply and demand side in 
three crucial industry sectors: textiles and garments, construction, and light engineering. In 
addition, a select group of nongovernment organizations (NGOs) involved in the development of 
nonfarm technical skills will be organized to address the needs for technical skills of the informal 
sector.

I.  POVERTY ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 
A.    Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
Bangladesh’s national poverty reduction strategy (NPRS) recognizes the potential contribution of technical and 
vocational education and training (TVET) to reducing poverty by providing employable skills, particularly to those who 
dropped out of school early and are already of employable age, and to the large pool of unemployed and 
underemployed adults. Skills training can play a major role in giving people income-earning opportunities. Skills 
training in occupational areas needed by the labor market increases the likelihood of employment and self-
employment of trainees. The poverty reduction strategy calls for reform of the TVET system by making it more 
market-responsive, addressing training needs of the underprivileged who do not complete class 8, collaborating with 
the private sector and nongovernment organizations (NGOs), and making its training programs more flexible in terms 
of duration, curriculum, and students’ academic qualifications, among others. 
The Skills Development Project (the Project) addresses the TVET needs in Bangladesh. Focusing mainly on short 
competency-based training (CBT) courses, the Project will open the formal TVET system to out-of-school youth who 
are of employable age, women, and unemployed and underemployed adults. It will extend the system’s reach to 
poverty areas in collaboration with its industry and NGO partners. The Project also aims to improve the relevance 
and quality of TVET programs.  
B.  Poverty Analysis                                                                  Targeting Classification: General intervention  
1.  Key Issues  
Bangladesh’s formal TVET system produces a low number of training graduates and thus has a minimal impact on 
poverty reduction. The main clientele are currently the youth, about three-quarters of whom are male, who complete 
class 8 and have strong white-collar job aspirations. The class 8 barrier, the minimum entry requirement to the formal 
TVET system, automatically excludes the large majority, many of whom are poor and do not complete schooling up 
to that level. The formal TVET system also does not recognize good training provided by agencies not under the 
umbrella of the Ministry of Education (MOE) nor does it recognize good training provided by NGOs. The relevance 
and quality of its formal training programs are low; employment and pass rates of graduates need to be increased. 
The matching of skills training programs need to be improved to increase the employment rates of trainees.  
Training programs can be made more flexible in terms of duration (more short-term, modular training) and academic 
qualifications (less than class 8), and made more relevant by coordinating with employers, industries, and NGOs. 
Quality can also be improved by providing training institutions with the appropriate equipment, a regular supply of 
training materials, and TVET teachers with pedagogical and technological training. 
2. Design Features 
The Project will strengthen the capacity of the TVET systems to provide market-responsive, short-term skills training 
to more Bangladeshis. Short, modular CBT courses will be developed and will provide greater flexibility, in terms of 
duration and academic qualification requirements. The training programs will not necessarily require class 8 for 
enrolment, which will expand access to the TVET system to those that did not reach this required level, many of 
whom are poor. The facilities of TVET institutions will be upgraded to expand the capacity for delivering short, 
relevant training programs and thus will provide more space for students. The Project will also establish training 
workshops in selected poor communities, which will make training more accessible to the poor. Thus, the Project will 
open TVET institutions to a larger number of trainees in short CBT courses, most of whom would have been denied 
access because of the class 8 barrier to entry. As the training programs will be demand-driven and based on 
industry-set or recognized standards, opportunities for employment and self-employment opportunities of trainees 
will improve.     
II.  SOCIAL ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 
A.  Findings of Social Analysis  
Bangladesh made big strides in human development from the 1980s to the 2000s. In education, the primary gross 
enrollment rate is over 100% and gender parity has been achieved in both primary and secondary education. 
Bangladesh’s population growth rate was halved over two decades, and infant mortality rates decreased by a quarter 
between 1989–1993 and 1995–1999. However, despite this progress, it has remained one of the poorest countries in 
the world, with more than half of its citizens living below the poverty line. Many Bangladeshi households are 
vulnerable to income risks. In addition to shocks faced by individuals, e.g. illness, death, and dowries, the country is 
prone to repeated natural disasters in the form of floods, droughts, cyclones, and riverbank erosion, which affect 
broad segments of the population. These challenges are compounded by a population density of roughly 800 people 
per square kilometer—one of the highest in the world. Although poverty in urban areas is lower than in rural areas, it

INDIGENOUS PEOPLES’ DEVELOPMENT FRAMEWORK  
 
A.   Proposed Strategies for Addressing Issues Related to Indigenous Peoples 
 
1.  During  project  implementation,  the  following  strategies  (Supplementary  Appendix  F 
provides  the  full  indigenous  peoples'  development  framework)  will  facilitate  addressing 
indigenous people issues: (i) In the Chittagong Hill Tract and other parts of Bangladesh with 
indigenous groups that are underserved, provision will be made to help ensure equitable access 
to  skills  training.  This  includes  provision  of  daily  training  allowance,  as  appropriate,  and 
accommodations in training institutions’ hostels, where available. (ii) The venue for skills training 
assisted by the Project will be open to all, including indigenous groups. (iii) In recruiting new 
teaching and training staff in communities with indigenous people, given equal qualifications, 
priority will be given to residents of the immediate community. (iv) A gender and indigenous 
peoples specialist will support project implementation, including helping develop a situation 
analysis, strategy, and action plan for the participation of indigenous people in skills training.  
(v) The project implementation unit (PIU) and the Directorate of Technical Education (DTE) will 
collect  project  baseline  ethnicity-disaggregated  data,  and,  thereafter,  regularly  collect  and 
maintain ethnicity-disaggregated data in its database. (vi) The PIU, in cooperation with DTE will 
regularly analyze project output and impact indicators, including by ethnicity.  
 
B.  Impact of the Project on Indigenous Peoples 
 
2.  The project activities are not expected to have a negative impact on indigenous people, 
rather, implementation will improve the quality and relevance of skills training for all who are 
eligible  and  would  like  to  avail  of  it.  This  will  contribute  to  increasing  the  likelihood  of 
employment after training.  
 
3.  With the increased interaction between government training program developers and the 
industry  through  sector  working  committees  (SWCs),  competency  standards  and  training 
curricula will have greater relevance to the needs of the labor market. The provision of in-
service  teacher  training  and  improvement  in  the  facilities  of  certain  training  programs  will 
improve the quality of training. The provision of training equipment will provide students with the 
opportunity to access practical training and thus improve the quality of their training.  
 
4.  More skills training programs will be offered in occupational areas immediately needed 
by  the  labor  market.  Training  will  be  short  and  competency-based,  with  the  competency 
standards  and  training  standards  specified  in  coordination  with  industries.  The  training 
admission  eligibility  standards  will  be  specified  in  coordination  with  industry  associations 
according to the occupations’ skill standards. Training programs will be open to everyone and 
will be held in venues that do not restrict admission to any indigenous group. Multipurpose 
training  workshops  will  be  constructed  in  poor  communities  for  skills  training  delivery;  the 
community skills training programs will respond to labor market needs. 
 
5.  By offering more short training programs that do not necessarily require completion of 
class 8 for eligibility, more Bangladeshis, including many indigenous people, will be able to avail 
of skills training. Daily training allowance will be provided to poor students, some of whom 
belong to indigenous groups, to reduce the cost of attendance. This will encourage them to 
enroll and complete their skills training programs.

C.  Procedures 
 
6.  The screening of project impacts on indigenous peoples is a continuing process that 
categorizes the impacts and identifies subsequent approaches and resource requirements to 
address  identified  issues.  Projects  are  categorized  by  the  significance  of  their  impacts  on 
indigenous people. The significance is decided by scrutinizing the type, location, scale, nature, 
and magnitude of a project’s potential impacts.  
 
7.  An indigenous peoples development framework is a policy and procedural framework for 
indigenous peoples development plans that are developed for subprojects, components, or 
investments, and are approved during loan implementation. The Government will prepare a 
specific action for indigenous people groups for subprojects with limited impacts on indigenous 
peoples or when there is a risk that the project may not bring intended benefits to the affected 
indigenous peoples within a specific plan. 
 
8.  An  indigenous  peoples  development  plan  addresses  (i)  aspirations,  needs,  and 
preferred  options  of  those  affected;  (ii)  local  social  organization,  cultural  beliefs,  ancestral 
territory, and resource use patterns among those affected; (iii) potential positive and negative 
impacts; (iv) measures to avoid, mitigate, or compensate for the adverse effects; (v) measures 
to ensure project benefits will accrue to indigenous peoples; (vi) measure to strengthen social, 
legal, and technical capabilities of government institutions to address indigenous people issues; 
(vii)  the  possibility  of  involving  local  organizations  and  nongovernment  organizations  with 
expertise in indigenous people issues; (viii) budget allocation; and (ix) monitoring. 
 
9.  An indigenous peoples’ specific action may take the form of (i) incorporating indigenous 
peoples (who might be excluded) into the project beneficiary group, (ii) incorporating indigenous 
peoples’ specific needs into the project plan, and (iii) a common community action plan where 
indigenous peoples live with non-indigenous peoples in the same project location. 
 
10.  The indigenous peoples development plans or specific actions will be submitted to the 
Asian Development Bank for review and concurrence. 
 
D.   Implementation Arrangements 
 
11.  The gender and indigenous peoples specialist will assist the PIU in implementing this 
strategy, including capacity-building of PIU and relevant DTE personnel for screening project 
activities. The project director, with the support of the head of the PIU monitoring and evaluation 
unit,  will  undertake  required  screening  for  project  impacts  on  indigenous  people.  Where 
applicable and necessary, the specialist will assist the PIU develop a corrective action plan for 
indigenous people to have equal access to the training program. 
 
E.   Monitoring and Evaluation 
 
12.  The Executing Agency, the Ministry of Education, will be responsible for monitoring and 
evaluation  of  activities  related  to  indigenous  peoples.  The  Project  will  collect  ethnicity-
disaggregated  data.  The  PIU  will  regularly  analyze  project  output  and  impact  indicators, 
including by ethnicity. The gender and indigenous people specialist will build the capacity of the 
PIU and relevant DTE personnel to collect ethnicity-disaggregated project data and ensure that 
monitoring  and  evaluation  procedures  include  indicators  for  monitoring  impact  on  the 
beneficiaries. Where applicable and despite all efforts, indigenous peoples still have unequal 
access to project skill development activities, DTE will provide funding from the project budget 
for a corrective action plan if such corrective action is necessary.
